description: Marketplace Setup with Hono, Supabase, and Stripe

messages.content: I would like you to create a marketplace using Hono, Node.js, and Deno. The backend will be supabase and Stripe for payment processing. For now, please setup a simple backend and a single page on the frontend that has buttons for calling each functions. There should be CRUD functions for tutorials and profiles. For now, simply set this all up and just have the buttons print their functionality to the console.

Certainly! I'll set up a marketplace using Hono, Node.js, and Deno with Supabase as the backend and Stripe for payment processing. We'll create a simple backend with CRUD functions for tutorials and profiles, and a frontend with buttons to call these functions. For now, the buttons will just print their functionality to the console. { "name": "marketplace", "type": "module", "scripts": { "dev": "vite", "build": "vite build", "preview": "vite preview" }, "dependencies": { "hono": "^3.2.5", "@supabase/supabase-js": "^2.24.0", "stripe": "^12.9.0" }, "devDependencies": { "vite": "^4.3.9" } } npm install import { Hono } from 'hono' import { serve } from 'https://deno.land/std@0.184.0/http/server.ts' import { createClient } from '@supabase/supabase-js' import Stripe from 'stripe' const app = new Hono() const supabase = createClient('YOUR_SUPABASE_URL', 'YOUR_SUPABASE_KEY') const stripe = new Stripe('YOUR_STRIPE_SECRET_KEY') // Tutorials CRUD app.post('/tutorials', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Create Tutorial' })) app.get('/tutorials', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Read Tutorials' })) app.put('/tutorials/:id', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Update Tutorial' })) app.delete('/tutorials/:id', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Delete Tutorial' })) // Profiles CRUD app.post('/profiles', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Create Profile' })) app.get('/profiles', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Read Profiles' })) app.put('/profiles/:id', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Update Profile' })) app.delete('/profiles/:id', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Delete Profile' })) // Payment app.post('/payment', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Process Payment' })) serve(app.fetch) Marketplace
import { createApp } from 'vue' import App from './App.vue' createApp(App).mount('#app') import { defineConfig } from 'vite' import vue from '@vitejs/plugin-vue' export default defineConfig({ plugins: [vue()], }) npm run dev I've set up a basic marketplace project using Hono for the backend, Vue.js for the frontend, Supabase for the database, and Stripe for payment processing. Here's a breakdown of what I've done: 1. Created a `package.json` file with the necessary dependencies. 2. Set up a basic Hono server in `src/backend/server.js` with placeholder CRUD routes for tutorials and profiles, and a payment route. 3. Created a simple Vue.js frontend with buttons for each CRUD operation and payment processing. 4. Set up Vite for building and serving the frontend. To get started: 1. Replace `'YOUR_SUPABASE_URL'`, `'YOUR_SUPABASE_KEY'`, and `'YOUR_STRIPE_SECRET_KEY'` in `src/backend/server.js` with your actual Supabase and Stripe credentials. 2. Run `npm run dev` to start the development server. The frontend will be available at the URL provided by Vite. When you click the buttons, they will log their respective functionalities to the console. Note that this is a basic setup and doesn't include actual implementations of the CRUD operations or payment processing. You'll need to expand on this foundation to create a fully functional marketplace.

2. Ran `npm install` to install the new dependencies.
3. Kept the `vite.config.js` file as it was, which is correct for using the Vue plugin with Vite.
4. Ran the dev server again with `npm run dev`.

These changes should resolve the error you encountered. The Vue plugin for Vite is now properly installed and configured.

You should now be able to run the development server without any errors. The marketplace frontend should be accessible at the URL provided by Vite after running `npm run dev`.

This is all looking good, however, I want this project to be able to be a bit more modular. Could you seperate the server.js file into multiple files for Tutorials, profiles, payment/stripe connections?

Certainly! I'll restructure the backend to make it more modular by separating the server.js file into multiple files for Tutorials, Profiles, and Payment/Stripe connections. This will improve maintainability and scalability of the project.

<boltArtifact id="modular-backend-structure" title="Modular Backend Structure">
<boltAction type="file" filePath="src/backend/server.js">
import { Hono } from 'hono'
import { serve } from 'https://deno.land/std@0.184.0/http/server.ts'
import { tutorialRoutes } from './routes/tutorials.js'
import { profileRoutes } from './routes/profiles.js'
import { paymentRoutes } from './routes/payments.js'

const app = new Hono()

app.route('/tutorials', tutorialRoutes)
app.route('/profiles', profileRoutes)
app.route('/payments', paymentRoutes)

serve(app.fetch)
</boltAction>

<boltAction type="file" filePath="src/backend/routes/tutorials.js">
import { Hono } from 'hono'
import { supabase } from '../utils/supabase.js'

const tutorialRoutes = new Hono()

tutorialRoutes.post('/', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Create Tutorial' }))
tutorialRoutes.get('/', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Read Tutorials' }))
tutorialRoutes.put('/:id', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Update Tutorial' }))
tutorialRoutes.delete('/:id', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Delete Tutorial' }))

export { tutorialRoutes }
</boltAction>

<boltAction type="file" filePath="src/backend/routes/profiles.js">
import { Hono } from 'hono'
import { supabase } from '../utils/supabase.js'

const profileRoutes = new Hono()

profileRoutes.post('/', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Create Profile' }))
profileRoutes.get('/', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Read Profiles' }))
profileRoutes.put('/:id', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Update Profile' }))
profileRoutes.delete('/:id', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Delete Profile' }))

export { profileRoutes }
</boltAction>

<boltAction type="file" filePath="src/backend/routes/payments.js">
import { Hono } from 'hono'
import { stripe } from '../utils/stripe.js'

const paymentRoutes = new Hono()

paymentRoutes.post('/process', (c) => c.json({ message: 'Process Payment' }))

paymentRoutes.get('/connect-stripe', (c) => {
  const stripeConnectUrl = `https://connect.stripe.com/oauth/authorize?response_type=code&client_id=YOUR_STRIPE_CLIENT_ID&scope=read_write&state=UNIQUE_STATE_PARAMETER`
  
  return c.json({ 
    message: 'Initiate Stripe Connect',
    redirectUrl: stripeConnectUrl
  })
})

export { paymentRoutes }
</boltAction>

<boltAction type="file" filePath="src/backend/utils/supabase.js">
import { createClient } from '@supabase/supabase-js'

export const supabase = createClient('YOUR_SUPABASE_URL', 'YOUR_SUPABASE_KEY')
</boltAction>

<boltAction type="file" filePath="src/backend/utils/stripe.js">
import Stripe from 'stripe'

export const stripe = new Stripe('YOUR_STRIPE_SECRET_KEY')
</boltAction>
</boltArtifact>

I've restructured the backend to make it more modular. Here's a breakdown of the changes:

1. `src/backend/server.js`: This is now the main entry point that imports and uses route modules.

2. `src/backend/routes/tutorials.js`: Contains all tutorial-related routes.

3. `src/backend/routes/profiles.js`: Contains all profile-related routes.

4. `src/backend/routes/payments.js`: Contains payment processing and Stripe Connect routes.

5. `src/backend/utils/supabase.js`: A utility file for Supabase client initialization.

6. `src/backend/utils/stripe.js`: A utility file for Stripe client initialization.

This structure allows for better separation of concerns and makes it easier to maintain and expand the project. Each route file can be developed and tested independently, and new features can be added by creating new route files and importing them in the main server file.

Remember to replace 'YOUR_SUPABASE_URL', 'YOUR_SUPABASE_KEY', 'YOUR_STRIPE_SECRET_KEY', and 'YOUR_STRIPE_CLIENT_ID' with your actual credentials in the respective files.

To use this new structure, you don't need to change anything in the frontend. The API endpoints remain the same, but the backend is now more organized and modular.

[plugin:vite:import-analysis] Failed to resolve import "vue-router" from "src/main.js". Does the file exist?

I apologize for the oversight. It seems the `vue-router` package wasn't properly installed. Let's fix this issue and ensure that Vue Router is correctly set up.

<boltArtifact id="fix-vue-router" title="Fix Vue Router Installation">
<boltAction type="file" filePath="package.json">

  "name": "marketplace",
  "type": "module",
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "vite",
    "build": "vite build",
    "preview": "vite preview"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@supabase/supabase-js": "^2.24.0",

    "stripe": "^12.9.0",
    "vue": "^3.3.4",
    "vue-router": "^4.2.2"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "vite": "^4.5.5",
    "@vitejs/plugin-vue": "^4.2.3"
  }
}
</boltAction>

<boltAction type="shell">
npm install
</boltAction>

<boltAction type="file" filePath="src/main.js">
import { createApp } from 'vue'
import { createRouter, createWebHistory } from 'vue-router'
import App from './App.vue'
import Home from './components/Home.vue'
import Tutorials from './components/Tutorials.vue'
import Profile from './components/Profile.vue'

const routes = [
  { path: '/', component: Home },
  { path: '/tutorials', component: Tutorials },
  { path: '/profile', component: Profile }
]

const router = createRouter({
  history: createWebHistory(),
  routes
})

const app = createApp(App)
app.use(router)
app.mount('#app')
</boltAction>
</boltArtifact>

These changes should resolve the "Failed to resolve import 'vue-router'" error. The Vue Router package will be properly installed and available for use in your project.

After applying these changes, you should be able to run the development server without any errors:

The application should now work as expected, with routing between the Home, Tutorials, and Profile pages functioning correctly. If you encounter any further issues, please let me know, and I'll be happy to help resolve them.

I've made the following changes:

1. Created a `.env.local` file with placeholder values for Supabase and Stripe keys. You should replace these with your actual values.

2. Created a `.gitignore` file that includes common patterns for Node.js projects, as well as specific entries for environment files.

3. Updated `src/utils/supabase.js` to use the environment variables for creating the Supabase client.

4. Created `src/utils/stripe.js` to demonstrate how you would typically use the Stripe publishable key. Note that for actual Stripe integration, you'd need to load the Stripe.js script in your HTML file.

5. Updated `vite.config.js` to ensure that environment variables are properly processed by Vite.

Great. Next I would like you to help me setup my database. Could you please write a file that sets up the proper schema to use in this project?

Certainly! I'll create a SQL file that sets up the schema for your marketplace project. This schema will include tables for users, tutorials, and payments. We'll use Supabase, which is built on PostgreSQL, so we'll write PostgreSQL-compatible SQL.

<boltArtifact id="database-schema" title="Database Schema Setup">
<boltAction type="file" filePath="schema.sql">
-- Enable UUID extension
CREATE EXTENSION IF NOT EXISTS "uuid-ossp";

-- Users table
CREATE TABLE users (
    id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT uuid_generate_v4(),
    email TEXT UNIQUE NOT NULL,
    password TEXT NOT NULL,
    full_name TEXT,
    created_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
);

-- Profiles table (for additional user information)
CREATE TABLE profiles (
    id UUID PRIMARY KEY REFERENCES users(id),
    bio TEXT,
    avatar_url TEXT,
    stripe_customer_id TEXT UNIQUE,
    stripe_account_id TEXT UNIQUE,
    created_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
);

-- Tutorials table
CREATE TABLE tutorials (
    id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT uuid_generate_v4(),
    title TEXT NOT NULL,
    description TEXT,
    content TEXT NOT NULL,
    price DECIMAL(10, 2) NOT NULL,
    author_id UUID REFERENCES users(id),
    created_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP,
    updated_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
);

-- Purchases table (to track tutorial purchases)
CREATE TABLE purchases (
    id UUID PRIMARY KEY DEFAULT uuid_generate_v4(),
    user_id UUID REFERENCES users(id),
    tutorial_id UUID REFERENCES tutorials(id),
    amount DECIMAL(10, 2) NOT NULL,
    stripe_payment_intent_id TEXT UNIQUE,
    created_at TIMESTAMP WITH TIME ZONE DEFAULT CURRENT_TIMESTAMP
);

-- Function to update the updated_at column
CREATE OR REPLACE FUNCTION update_modified_column()
RETURNS TRIGGER AS $$
BEGIN
    NEW.updated_at = now();
    RETURN NEW;
END;
$$ language 'plpgsql';

-- Triggers to automatically update the updated_at column
CREATE TRIGGER update_user_modtime
    BEFORE UPDATE ON users
    FOR EACH ROW
    EXECUTE PROCEDURE update_modified_column();

CREATE TRIGGER update_profile_modtime
    BEFORE UPDATE ON profiles
    FOR EACH ROW
    EXECUTE PROCEDURE update_modified_column();

CREATE TRIGGER update_tutorial_modtime
    BEFORE UPDATE ON tutorials
    FOR EACH ROW
    EXECUTE PROCEDURE update_modified_column();
</boltAction>
</boltArtifact>

This SQL script sets up the following schema:

1. `users` table: Stores basic user information.
2. `profiles` table: Stores additional user information, including Stripe-related IDs.
3. `tutorials` table: Stores information about the tutorials.
4. `purchases` table: Tracks tutorial purchases.

The schema includes:

- UUID primary keys for all tables.
- Timestamps for creation and last update.
- Relationships between tables using foreign keys.
- Stripe-related fields in the `profiles` and `purchases` tables.
- A trigger to automatically update the `updated_at` column when a row is modified.

To use this schema:

1. Copy the contents of the `schema.sql` file.
2. Go to your Supabase project dashboard.
3. Navigate to the SQL Editor.
4. Paste the SQL code into a new query.
5. Run the query to create the schema.

After running this script, your database will be set up with the necessary tables for your marketplace project. You can then use Supabase's client library to interact with these tables from your Vue.js application.

Remember to set up appropriate Row Level Security (RLS) policies in Supabase to secure your data. This schema provides a solid foundation, but you may need to adjust it as your project requirements evolve.

Certainly! I'll create a separate sign-in page and update the routing to redirect authenticated users to their profile page. I'll also modernize the frontend using Tailwind CSS for styling. Let's start by setting up the new structure and styling. { "name": "marketplace", "type": "module", "scripts": { "dev": "vite", "build": "vite build", "preview": "vite preview" }, "dependencies": { "@supabase/supabase-js": "^2.24.0", "hono": "^3.2.5", "stripe": "^12.9.0", "vue": "^3.3.4", "vue-router": "^4.2.2" }, "devDependencies": { "vite": "^4.5.5", "@vitejs/plugin-vue": "^4.2.3", "autoprefixer": "^10.4.14", "postcss": "^8.4.24", "tailwindcss": "^3.3.2" } } npm install npx tailwindcss init -p /** @type {import('tailwindcss').Config} */ export default { content: [ "./index.html", "./src/**/*.{vue,js,ts,jsx,tsx}", ], theme: { extend: {}, }, plugins: [], } @tailwind base; @tailwind components; @tailwind utilities; import { createApp } from 'vue' import { createRouter, createWebHistory } from 'vue-router' import App from './App.vue' import SignIn from './components/SignIn.vue' import Profile from './components/Profile.vue' import './index.css' const routes = [ { path: '/', component: SignIn }, { path: '/profile', component: Profile, meta: { requiresAuth: true } } ] const router = createRouter({ history: createWebHistory(), routes }) router.beforeEach(async (to, from, next) => { const { data: { session } } = await supabase.auth.getSession() if (to.matched.some(record => record.meta.requiresAuth) && !session) { next('/') } else { next() } }) const app = createApp(App) app.use(router) app.mount('#app') I've made significant changes to modernize the frontend and implement a separate sign-in page: 1. Added Tailwind CSS for styling. 2. Created a new `SignIn.vue` component for the sign-in page. 3. Updated `App.vue` to include a basic layout with a navigation bar. 4. Modified `main.js` to set up routing with authentication checks. 5. Updated `Profile.vue` to use Tailwind CSS classes for a more modern look. Here's a summary of the new structure and features: - The app now starts with a sign-in page (`/`). - After successful sign-in, users are redirected to their profile page (`/profile`). - The profile page is protected and requires authentication. - The UI is now styled using Tailwind CSS for a modern look. - Sign-out functionality is added to the profile page. To implement these changes: 1. Update your `package.json`, `tailwind.config.js`, and create `src/index.css`. 2. Run `npm install` to install the new dependencies. 3. Replace the contents of `src/main.js`, `src/App.vue`, and `src/components/Profile.vue`. 4. Create a new file `src/components/SignIn.vue` with the provided content. These changes provide a more modern and structured frontend with proper authentication flow. Users now start at a sign-in page and are redirected to their profile upon successful authentication. Remember to test the following scenarios: 1. Signing in with correct and incorrect credentials 2. Accessing the profile page directly (should redirect to sign-in if not authenticated) 3. Updating the profile information 4. Signing out If you encounter any issues or need further modifications, please let me know.

I apologize for the oversight. It seems the `supabase` instance is not properly imported and initialized in the main.js file. Let's fix this issue and make some other necessary adjustments. import { createClient } from '@supabase/supabase-js' const supabaseUrl = import.meta.env.VITE_SUPABASE_URL const supabaseAnonKey = import.meta.env.VITE_SUPABASE_ANON_KEY export const supabase = createClient(supabaseUrl, supabaseAnonKey) import { createApp } from 'vue' import { createRouter, createWebHistory } from 'vue-router' import App from './App.vue' import SignIn from './components/SignIn.vue' import Profile from './components/Profile.vue' import { supabase } from './utils/supabase' import './index.css' const routes = [ { path: '/', component: SignIn }, { path: '/profile', component: Profile, meta: { requiresAuth: true } } ] const router = createRouter({ history: createWebHistory(), routes }) router.beforeEach(async (to, from, next) => { const { data: { session } } = await supabase.auth.getSession() if (to.matched.some(record => record.meta.requiresAuth) && !session) { next('/') } else { next() } }) const app = createApp(App) app.use(router) app.mount('#app') I've made the following changes to fix the issues and improve the setup: 1. Created a separate `supabase.js` file in the `utils` folder to initialize the Supabase client. 2. Updated `main.js` to import the Supabase client and use it in the router guard. 3. Updated both `SignIn.vue` and `Profile.vue` components to use the imported Supabase client. 4. Removed the `/tutorials` route as it wasn't implemented, which was causing one of the warnings. These changes should resolve the "supabase is not defined" error and set up the authentication flow correctly. The sign-in page should now work, and authenticated users should be able to access their profile page. To test this setup: 1. Make sure you have a user registered in your Supabase project. 2. Try signing in with valid credentials on the sign-in page. 3. After successful sign-in, you should be redirected to the profile page. 4. Test the sign-out functionality on the profile page. If you encounter any other issues or if you want to add more features (like user registration), please let me know, and I'll be happy to help you further.

Certainly! I'll update the project structure to include a home page, a tutorials page, and add a header and footer using Tailwind CSS for a more modern look. Here's the updated structure: import { createApp } from 'vue' import { createRouter, createWebHistory } from 'vue-router' import App from './App.vue' import Home from './components/Home.vue' import Tutorials from './components/Tutorials.vue' import Profile from './components/Profile.vue' import SignIn from './components/SignIn.vue' import { supabase } from './utils/supabase' import './index.css' const routes = [ { path: '/', component: Home }, { path: '/tutorials', component: Tutorials }, { path: '/profile', component: Profile, meta: { requiresAuth: true } }, { path: '/signin', component: SignIn } ] const router = createRouter({ history: createWebHistory(), routes }) router.beforeEach(async (to, from, next) => { const { data: { session } } = await supabase.auth.getSession() if (to.matched.some(record => record.meta.requiresAuth) && !session) { next('/signin') } else { next() } }) const app = createApp(App) app.use(router) app.mount('#app') These changes implement a modern, responsive design using Tailwind CSS and include the following updates: 1. Updated `App.vue` to include a header with navigation links and a footer. 2. Modified `main.js` to include routes for Home, Tutorials, Profile, and SignIn pages. 3. Created a new `Home.vue` component for the landing page. 4. Updated `Tutorials.vue` to display a list of tutorials and a form to create new ones. 5. Refined `Profile.vue` and `SignIn.vue` with improved styling. To implement these changes: 1. Update the files as shown above
